Troops of the army march out to the streets, inmediatly joined by paramilitries and armed groups of the right. The lines are soon drawn and forces loyal and against the goverment prepare to face off.
With our resources, the Center are convinced to support Azaña over Alcala Zamora.

content.content: There is no path to an obviously workable majority. Since President Alcala Zamora is unwilling to work with a minority or caretaker PSOE or CEDA government, his preferred chancellor is Manuel Portela, and independent centrist Republican, who could lead a "presidential" government.
We do not have good enough relations with the Communists, so they are not even willing to accept our support.
The reformist faction is able to dissuade the party from supporting this bizarre arrangement.

The Center Party is confused at our capricious behavior, and have switched their support to Alcala Zamora.

There is no path to a majority government. President Alcala Zamora is tired of the chaos, and appoints Franz von Papen as chancellor instead of Brüning. Papen is a indenpendent formerly from the Center Party, and is significantly to the right of the majority of the Center Party.
Papen is immediately faced with a vote of no confidence, given his unpopularity. However the PSOE votes, he is guaranteed to fall, due to the unanimous hatred against him from all other parties.

content.content: There is no path to a majority government. One option would be to have a continuation of the current Brüning government; if we tolerate it, then it would retain a majority vote against no-confidence.

Alternatively, we could try to form a "new grand coalition" of all constitutional parties except the FE_JONS, PCE, and CEDA. The stumbling block are the minor conservative parties such as the "Economic Party of the Middle Class", who detest any hint of socialism and would ruin the country before working with Marxists.
The third option is to have new elections.

Manuel Azana for Chancellor? This will be a bitter pill for our rightmost coalition partners but perhaps its worth it.

content.content: We transfer some of our campaign funds to our putative coalition partners. Some would call this corruption, but perhaps it is necessary to save our democracy.
Now, we have a new grand coalition, a "Constitutional Coalition" of all the non-fascist and non-communist parties. Leftists in our party are frontally against this arrangement.
Who should be chancellor?
As expected, the incumbent Alcala Zamora wins the presidency. Let's hope he continues to keep the Nazis out of power.

Manuel Azaña of the PSOE has won the presidency! This is a moment of celebration for our party, and his victory is able to bolster our support.

options.title: No, we will not accept this offer.

content.content: The Center Party leader, Joseph Joos, clearly sees the threat from the ascension of the anti-democratic extremist parties, and thus tries to negotiate a "Government of National Unity" to save the republic. This coalition would be led by Joseph Wirth, a left-leaning member of the Center Party and former chancellor, and would encompass all of the constitutional parties. Our role in this government might be limited, however.

shuffle_leadership.add_juchacz.title: Marie Juchacz
shuffle_leadership.add_juchacz.subtitle: Marie Juchacz is the founder of Worker's Welfare, a mutual-aid organization.

content.content: Marie Juchacz is now an advisor.
We have formed a new unity government of all the constitutional parties! We have a limited choice in ministries for this government.

shuffle_leadership.add_pfulf.subtitle: Antonie Pfülf is a leader in social policy and women's rights.

options.title: We will tolerate a minority government led by Brüning.
We will tolerate a minority government led by Joseph Wirth.

content.content: Our rejection of the unity government has hurt our relations with the bourgeois and center-right parties.

There is no path to a majority government. Alcala Zamora is displeased with Portela, and calls on him to resign. Now, conservative republican Miguel Maura has been appointed President of Goverment, again as part of a presidential government.

Maura's government is deeply unpopular among all parties of the Cortes. Despite his support for a National Republican Dictatorship from the right of the PSOE to the left of the CEDA, it is hard to say if he will survive.

content: There is no path to a majority government for now. The scheming around President Alcala Zamora is leading to only one path - that of Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

election_1928.azanas_dilemma.title: There is no clear governing majority.

We will have new elections.

content.content: President Azana faces a dilemma. He desperately desires a socialist or at least democratic government, but the electoral results are not there for such. Article 48 has been used by Alcala Zamora to promulgate anti-democratic and anti-worker policies; can Article 48 be used for good as well as evil?

options.title: The Nazis immediately call a no-confidence vote against us...

content.content: Our experts have checked the constitution, and have discovered that there is no specific prohibition against the President of Goverment also being the President of the Republic.

Thus, we have President-President Manuel Azana. He claims that he will resign as soon as the economic-political crisis is over. The right-wing parties, who were once clamoring to replace parliamentary rule with dictatorship or monarchy, are now clamoring for the restoration of democracy.

content.content: We have appointed Indalecio Prieto as minority President. Appointing a socialist to minority goverment will not sit well with anyone to the right of the left republicans but perhaps this is necessary.

content.content: Changing the leadership of the party is painful, but perhaps it is necessary to adapt to changing circumstances.
Removing advisors will increase dissent from their faction of the party, while selecting advisors will increase a faction's strength and reduce their dissent.

options.title: It is war.

content.content: The military parties, seeing that we are willing to deny them government by questionably democratic means, have decided that they can only take power by undemocratic means, and have risen up in force against the sitting government.
Their numbers are bolstered by the many government workers who are against the prospect of a unified Socialist government. Police and soldiers defect to the SA and Stahlhelm.

content.content: We have won the vote of no confidence, and are currently ruling under an PSOE minority government. Now our task is to fix the country.

content.content: We have enough votes to form a "Socialist-Republican" government consisting of the PSOE, and Left Republican parties! This has been our preferred governing coalition.

content: There are enough votes to form a majority coalition consisting of the PSOE, Radical Republicans (PRR), Esquerra (ERC), and theh Left Republican (IR) parties. Given our rather weak electoral performance,

content.content: and our previous vote of no confidence against the government,

content: President Alcala Zamora has asked the Radicals to take the lead role in forming a government.

options.title: Join the Grand coalition.
Join the opposition.
We will "tolerate" a minority Republican government.

content: The Radicala President of Goverment is likely to be Alejandro Lerroux of the PRR

content.content: again

content: . He is known for his opportunism and sympathy for the right, being on the right wing of the PRR.

content.content: Due to the government's austerity policies, many of our members are reluctant to participate in this coalition again. Some support a "toleration" arrangement in which we will provide outside support to prevent the far-right from either entering government or calling a successful no-confidence vote. Some support entering into pure opposition, and letting the right do what it wishes.
Albeit Lerroux would prefer to exclude us, he is pressured by his party to not enter coalition with the monarchists. Alternatively, we could enter a "toleration" agreement.
Lerroux reluctantly welcomes us into his new cabinet. Now, we have our pick of ministries.

options.title: Join the Right coalition.
We will tolerate Brüning after all.
New elections, it is!

content: By refusing to join the grand coalition or tolerating it, we essentially throw the balance of government to the right wing.

content.content: There are enough votes to form a right-wing coalition that includes the CEDA. However, the CEDA leader, Gil Robles, is opposed to a coalition with the Republicans of the PRR. And of course, the fe_jons is not interested in coalition government. This means that there will not be enough votes to form a majority coalition.

There are not enough votes to form a right-wing coalition that includes the CEDA, and they are not interested in joining in a coalition with the Republicans if they refuse him the Presidency of Goverment. This means that there is no route to a majority coalition.

If we do not at least "tolerate" the government, there will be new elections in a few months. In the meantime, the President and President of Goverment may use the emergency powers to essentially govern by decree. And it is not at all clear that we will do any better in the next election.

content: There is no path to a workable Cortes majority or minority government. The next elections are set for

content.content: The people's faith in democracy is shaken by this ordeal. Of course, the CEDA amd far rogjt are exploiting the instability to claim that democracy is unworkable, and that Spain needs a strong leader.

election_1928.tolerating_portela.unavailableSubtitle: The parties supporting Brüning do not have a majority.

content.content: We have decided to tolerate Brüning's government. This means that we will vote against no-confidence votes to make sure they fail, but also that we will not be directly participating as ministers in the government. Thus, we can prevent a new election and stop the far right from entering government.

election_1928.toleration_right.unavailableSubtitle: The parties supporting the goverment do not have a majority.

content.content: We have decided to tolerate the rightist Republican government. This means that we will vote against no-confidence votes to make sure they fail, but also that we will not be directly participating as ministers in the government. Thus, we can prevent a new election and stop the far right from entering government.

options.title: Thus, there is no clear majority.
Perhaps a right-wing coalition may form.
Perhaps we could ask the PRP to change their minds?
What are the other governing arrangements?

content.content: Unfortunately, the PRP and PRR are unwilling to enter into another coalition with the PSOE, so the grand coalition is unable to be formed.
Under the influence of Gustav Stresemann, the PRP agrees to allow us into the coalition, and so does the PNV.

options.title: But they would not have a majority without the PSOE! The CEDA and far right have no interest in participating in government.
There is no chance that we would agree.
Perhaps Azana can do something?
What are the other governing arrangements?

content.content: The PRR asks us to adhere to their conservative economic policies (that is, austerity and labor discipline) in exchange for us joining the coalition.
We make the case that without the PSOE, there is no parliamentary majority, given the CEDA and Far Right's hostility to constitutional government.
Somehow, we succeed in convincing them! We are now in a coalition.
As expected, the PRP is too set in their anti-socialist ways.

content: As expected, the PSOE is the largest party, and this time, we are expected to take the lead role in the formation of the next government, including selecting the chancellor. President
has asked us to form a majority coalition with the Center (Z), Bavarian People's (PNV), Democratic (IR), and People's (PRP) parties.

content.content: As our relation with the PRP is poor, they are demanding more minister posts in order to remain part of the coalition.
Who should be the chancellor?

election_1928.prieto.subtitle: prieto is popular within the party, and is the preferred candidate of the Center and other parties.

content.content: Prieto's appointment as chancellor is approved by all our potential allies.
Azana is approved by the members of the coalition.

election_1928.prr_chancellor.subtitle: This is unexpected and will cause internal dissent, but may give us a better position in negotiating for other cabinet positions.

content.content: This is highly unexpected, and many in the left and center of our party are criticizing this decision.
Since Lerroux is desliked by the left, Martinez Barrios has been appointed chancellor.

election_1928.no_govt.title: We do not form the government.
election_1928.no_govt.subtitle: This will cause significant internal dissent, and will lead to increased distrust from the bourgeois parties.

options.title: Yes, we're sure.

content: Are we sure about not participating in government? This will cause significant internal dissent, and will lead to increased distrust from the bourgeois parties. Even debating this option causes internal backlash. In addition, it is possible that the bourgeois and right-wing parties will also be unable to form a coalition government, leading to a regime appointed by President

options.title: We hope to reach a socialist majority in the next election.
It is a trap to form a government now. We would be unable to accomplish our goals.
Revolutionary socialism is our goal.

content.content: What are our goals here, exactly?

There are enough votes to form a right-wing coalition of the PRR, PRP, CEDA, and various minor parties, essentially forming a Right Wing Goverment. However, the CEDA is very reluctant to join the government.
President of Goverment Lerroux of the Radical Republlican Party currently rules on a Right Wing Coalition.

content: Since the remaining bourgeois and right-wing parties cannot form a tolerable governing agreement, new elections have been called for
. The previous President of Goverment has resigned, and has been replaced by Manuel Portela, a liberal Independant, ruling as part of a presidential cabinet.

content.content: We are seen as responsible for the failure to form a government, and many of our middle-class and even some working-class supporters have deserted the party.

content: We can pick from any number of ministries. Controlling a ministry allows us to directly effect policy in that area.

content.content: Any ministry that we do not take will be given to the PCE.
If the PCE controls the Reichswehr Ministry, the army will most likely revolt.
